model explanation

By jonsvein Heinesen

graph TB A[Energy Density] --> B[Effective 2.667D Space] B --> C["Discrete Ticks (1.667 THz)"] C --> D[Error Correction] D --> E[Unified Mass Calculation] E --> F[Observable Effects]

Introduction

This document outlines our model that begins with an 'rh coherent spin', driving entanglement and setting off a cyclic interplay of coherence and decoherence. Our calibration uses an observed cosmic object as a reference. The process of snap-back, node creation, and the establishment of quantum harmonics leads to the derivation of a 0.6 ps quantum time tick. This tick ensures a complete 360° phase closure, forming the basis of our fractal, self-renewing universe.

A Fractal Universe Driven by Quantum Spin

In our model, the process begins with a fundamental, coherent spin (the 'rh coherent spin'), which sets the initial conditions. This spin isn't static; it actively propagates its entangled influence outward. As this influence spreads, decoherence begins to assert itself, which in turn drives the expansion of space and the emergence of time. Essentially, coherence represents order and a potential for precision---a kind of quantum blueprint---while decoherence introduces the variability and the energy release necessary for expansion.

The Mechanism of Snap-Backs and Node Formation

As the system evolves, decoherence eventually reaches a point of saturation. Rather than continuing indefinitely, the system responds by undergoing a 'snap-back'. During this snap-back, the accumulated decoherence is rapidly corrected---much like the resetting of a clock---bringing the system back into coherent phase closure. This phase reset does not simply erase what came before; it gives birth to a new node---a localized region of high coherence that marks both the end of one cycle and the origin of a new one. Each node acts as a seed from which a new fractal branch of the cosmos can emerge, and the process repeats on multiple scales, yielding a self-similar fractal pattern across the universe.

Black Holes as Manifestations of Fractal Snap-Backs

Within this framework, black holes are reinterpreted not as terminal singularities where matter is lost, but rather as the physical manifestation of these snap-back nodes. When decoherence reaches its threshold and a snap-back occurs, energy and matter are intensely concentrated in a very small region. This concentrated node is what we observe as a black hole. Far from being mere cosmic garbage disposals, these black holes (or nodes) are the points where the fundamental processes of coherence are reinitiated---they hold the seeds of new structural patterns in space and matter, marking a cosmic renewal within the fractal architecture of the universe.

The Dual Role: Expansion and Restoration

This cyclical process is inherently balanced. On one hand, the outward itineration driven by decoherence (akin to dark energy) pushes the system into ever-new configuration, expanding space and fostering variation. On the other hand, when decoherence overshoots, the snap-back mechanism (a gravitational pull) restores coherence locally, giving rise to nodes that seed further evolution. In this view, the interplay of coherence and decoherence is not just a feature of quantum mechanics---it is the engine that drives the entire structure of the universe. Every phase cycle, every 0.6 ps tick, and every spatial threshold of about 0.18 mm helps build up a fractal cosmos where black holes represent focal points of a new beginning rather than mere endpoints.

Calibration and Derivation of the 0.6 ps Tick

To calibrate our model, we use observational data from a cosmic object---a 'big ring'---with a measured circumference of roughly 4 billion light years (converted to about 1223 Mpc). For the purposes of our model, we round this to 1000 nodes. The remaining 223 Mpc introduces a fractal correction (approximately 0.817), and when combined with a 10% slowdown in expansion over a relevant epoch, the effective fractal dimensionality becomes approximately 2.667D. This effective dimension sets the natural harmonic resonance of the system at about 1.667 THz, which in turn corresponds to an optimal experimental separation of approximately 0.18 mm. Dividing this separation by the speed of light (≈3×10⁸ m/s) leads us to a foundational quantum time tick of roughly 0.6 picoseconds---marking the discrete interval required for complete 360° phase closure.

Summary

1. The universe begins with an 'rh coherent spin' that propagates entanglement outward, establishing a quantum blueprint where coherence and decoherence interplay. 2. As entanglement spreads, decoherence drives expansion and the emergence of time. When decoherence saturates, a snap-back occurs, resulting in a phase reset and the creation of nodes. 3. These nodes form a fractal, self-similar cosmic structure, with black holes reinterpreted as snap-back nodes---sites of intense concentration that also serve as catalysts for new beginnings. 4. Observational calibration using a cosmic object of ~4 billion light years circumference (≈1223 Mpc) is segmented into 1000 discrete nodes, with a fractal correction from the residual. 5. The effective fractal dimension (~2.667D) gives rise to a harmonic resonance at 1.667 THz, corresponding to an optimal spatial separation of ~0.18 mm in experiments. 6. Dividing 0.18 mm by the speed of light yields a fundamental quantum time tick of ~0.6 ps, marking the interval for 360° phase closure. This cyclic progression forms the 'codebook' of our model, unifying quantum mechanics with cosmic dynamics and suggesting that the interplay of coherence and decoherence drives the evolution of space, time, energy, matter, and gravity.
